answers.body_markdown:
To use them as helper functions you need to first remove *partiality* from your code by using `Maybe`:

    treeBSMax :: (Ord a) => BSTree a -> Maybe a
    treeBSMax   btree = case btree of
            Null -> Nothing
            Node _ val Null -> Just val
            Node _ val right -> treeBSMax right
    
    treeBSMin :: (Ord a) => BSTree a -> Maybe a
    treeBSMin btree = case btree of
           Null -> Nothing
           Node Null val _ -> Just val
           Node left val _ -> treeBSMin left
    
    isBSTree :: (Ord a) => BinaryTree a -> Bool
    isBSTree btree = case btree of
          Null -> True                       -- changed it!
          Node Null val Null -> True
          Node lt val rt -> isBSTree lt       -- these two lines
                            && isBSTree rt     -- were missing !!
                            && inOrder (treeBSMax lt) val (treeBSMin rt)
                     where
                     inOrder Nothing  _ Nothing   =  True
                     inOrder Nothing  v (Just y)  =  v <= y
                     inOrder (Just x) v Nothing   =  x <= v
                     inOrder (Just x) v (Just y)  =  x <= v && v <= y

This is not efficient of course. (*why* is left as an exercise)
answers.title: Binary search tree predicate with helper functions

items.body_markdown:
data BinaryTree a = Null | Node (BinaryTree a) a (BinaryTree a)
    deriving Show

    type BSTree a = BinaryTree a

    treeBSMax :: (Ord a) => BSTree a -> a
    treeBSMax   btree = case btree of
            Null -> error
            Node _ val Null -> val
            Node _ val right -> treeBSMax right

    treeBSMin :: (Ord a) => BSTree a -> a
    treeBSMin btree = case btree of
           Null -> error
           Node Null val _ -> val
           Node left val _ -> treeBSMax left

    isBSTree :: (Ord a) => BinaryTree a -> Bool
    isBSTree btree = case btree of
          Null -> False
          Node Null val Null -> True
          Node lt val rt -> val >  treeBSMin lt && val < treeBSMax rt

How can I use `treeBSMin` and `treeBSMax` as helper functions of `isBSTree` to find whether a tree is a binary search tree?
items.title: Binary search tree predicate with helper functions

The content of a PDF file **always** begins with the string `%PDF`

in base64 this is `JVBERi`

answers.title: StringBuilder.Append puts text in the new line in case of long string C#

answers.body_markdown:
String builder has nothing to do with new lines unless there is a `\n` or you append manually a a `System.getProperty("line.separator")`. The only thing that changes with the length of the string is the memory allocation.



Here you have a part of documentation explaining it:

The StringBuilder.Length property indicates the number of characters the StringBuilder object currently contains. If you add characters to the StringBuilder object, its length increases until it equals the size of the StringBuilder.Capacity property, which defines the number of characters that the object can contain. If the number of added characters causes the length of the StringBuilder object to exceed its current capacity, new memory is allocated, the value of the Capacity property is doubled, new characters are added to the StringBuilder object, and its Length property is adjusted. Additional memory for the StringBuilder object is allocated dynamically until it reaches the value defined by the StringBuilder.MaxCapacity property. When the maximum capacity is reached, no further memory can be allocated for the StringBuilder object, and trying to add characters or expand it beyond its maximum capacity throws either an ArgumentOutOfRangeException or an OutOfMemoryException exception.

For more info you can check the official microsoft thread:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.text.stringbuilder?view=netframework-4.8

In case that any of your strings contain a `\n`, your problem is that the tool you use for visualizing the text is wrapping it on a new line.
answers.title: StringBuilder.Append puts text in the new line in case of long string C#

answers.body_markdown:
Aliases don't get inherited between subshells, so it's not currently possible to pass those through `$SINGULARITY_ENVIRONMENT` or `%environment`.

One option is to convert the aliases to functions:

From:
```bash
alias build_command='pushd build_dir && ./configure && make && make install && popd'
```

To:
```bash
build_command() { pushd build_dir && ./configure && make && make install && popd ; }
export -f build_command
```

However, Singularity uses `/bin/sh` by default for the initial environment processing and Debian-based systems have `/bin/sh` symlinked to `/bin/dash` and dash does not support export functions to subshells that I have found. You might be stuck manually sourcing a file with the aliases/functions if using an OS in the Debian family.

---

<s>In the `%post` section of your definition, you can echo into `$SINGULARITY_ENVIRONMENT`. 

[From the docs][1]:

```
%post
    apt-get update && apt-get install -y netcat
    NOW=`date`
    echo "export NOW=\"${NOW}\"" >> $SINGULARITY_ENVIRONMENT
```

In your case, you would do `echo "alias something='something else' >> $SINGULARITY_ENVIRONMENT`. It is important to do the append redirect `>>`, as you don't want to clobber the existing environment file. </s>


  [1]: https://sylabs.io/guides/3.4/user-guide/definition_files.html#post

Port 3306 defaults to the classic MySQL Wire Protocol. The MySQL X DevAPI Connector for Node.js only supports the X Protocol, which is implemented by the X Plugin (by default on port 33060).

You can change this by updating the `mysqlx_port` server variable or using the `--mysqlx-port=` option when starting the server. If you want to use the X Protocol on port 3306 though you will also have to update the `port` variable or use a different value with the `--port=` option when starting the server.

Disclaimer: I'm the lead developer of the MySQL X DevAPI Connector for Node.js

answers.body_markdown:
If you're using Flask app, you can host your app in Gunicorn with multiple workers and threads which allows parallelism by running multiple workers.

Gunicorn launches a master process that can create multiple (configured workers) where each worker can handle an HTTP request independently. The kernel handles the load balancing of request among the workers. 

If you add Gevent to the mix, that also provides concurrency per worker i.e. each worker would be able to handle multiple requests concurrently (not in parallel).

Both of these are available as pip packages, Gevent requires the installation of libev. 

The support for flask by Gunicorn is ensured by the fact that flask is a WSGI framework and Gunicorn is a WSGI server, they're simply plugged into each other.

answers.body_markdown:
You're not actually transposing, you're pivoting.

Pivot field `label`, with field `value` in values:

    = Table.Pivot(#"Previous Step", List.Distinct(#"Previous Step"[label]), "label", "value", List.Sum)

**EDIT**: 

With strings in the `value` field, simply choose not to aggregate the values:

    = Table.Pivot(#"Previous Step", List.Distinct(#"Previous Step"[label]), "label", "value")

This will return an error if you have multiple string values per row / column combination, though. In that case, you may wish to combine values:

    = Table.Pivot(#"Previous Step", List.Distinct(#"Previous Step"[label]), "label", "value", each Text.Combine(_, ", "))

It all depends on the context of what you are trying to achieve. If it is a service that should serve streaming media requests and be scalable and available - then it is rather a serious architecture design problem than just a Spring Boot method. Even if it's just a sandbox experimental project, you still need to be more specific on **what's the type of the app that you are building** (web app with rest API, a unix service process, just an executable program or anything else) and **who is the client** (where do you stream).  
Moreover, video streaming and audio streaming - those are 2 different worlds (different codecs, http headers and other nuances).   

[Here][1] is a pretty good observation on how to build a video streaming web-service with Spring Boot. Also, [this][2] discussion suggests using [Spring Content][3].
I took shots in the dark. Do your own research based on what exactly you need.

PS: "please help", "Thank you for your support in advance" - those things are needless here as they don't carry any informational value: when you post a question, it is obvious that you request a help, if you want to thank - upvote and accept answers. Next time, try avoiding those and be more specific in order to ask [good questions][4].

answers.body_markdown: It is the set of all `xs` where `mu(x)` is larger than `alpha`. In your example, assume `alpha` is 0.2. Then the alpha-cut is `{3,4,5}` because all of those `xs` have membership values greater than 0.2.
answers.title: Alpha cut in fuzzy logic

answers.body_markdown:
An -cut of a fuzzy set A is a crisp set A[] that contains all the elements of the universal set of U that have a membership grade in A greater than or equal to the specified value of [].

So for a fuzzy set A = { 0/1 + 0.1/2 + 0.4/3 + 0.5/4 + 0.5/5 }. Suppose  = 0.1.
Then **-cut**(>= relation) for A will be {2, 3, 4, 5} and **strict -cut**(> relation) will be {3, 4, 5}. Though generally -cut are consider as non-strict i.e >= type relation.

Another example, Suppose  = 0.3 then -cut will be {3, 4, 5} since all of them have µ(x)  .

answers.body_markdown:
You could make a DLC package that can be downloaded only once with the relatively new Adressable Assets system https://docs.unity3d.com/Packages/com.unity.addressables@0.4/manual/index.html. 

Lets say you have a map, and you make an addressable asset out of it. Basicly you would have a catalog file that would point to a version of your map (adressable), and when you would want to make a DLC you could just make a new version of that scene and package it as a new version of the adressable and the next time the players app checks if anything new is available it could see the new map and download it. You also have custom controll over which group of people could get the update and so on.

answers.body_markdown:
[Duplicate of [another answer](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/58317151/how-to-connect-mysql-to-node-js-using-xdevapi-connector-with-3306-port) of mine]

Port 3306 defaults to the classic MySQL Wire Protocol. The MySQL X DevAPI Connector for Node.js only supports the X Protocol, which is implemented by the X Plugin (by default on port 33060).

You can change this by updating the mysqlx_port server variable or using the --mysqlx-port= option when starting the server. If you want to use the X Protocol on port 3306 though you will also have to update the port variable or use a different value with the --port= option when starting the server.

Disclaimer: I'm the lead developer of the MySQL X DevAPI Connector for Node.js

answers.body_markdown:
So after a few time investigating, I discovered remaining login attempts were all made via blog editor apps.

The last openned gate to my dashboard login was the WordPress `xmlrpc.php` file,  a system that allows remote updates to WordPress from other applications.

So I decided to block it via .htaccess in Wordpress Root directory.

    <Files xmlrpc.php>
    order allow,deny
    deny from all
    </Files>
In addition to the previous rules as described in my own question
htaccess in the Wordpress root directory

    <Files wp-login.php>
    Order Deny,Allow
    Deny from all
    Allow from xx.xxx.xx.x
    </Files>
    <Files xmlrpc.php>
     order allow,deny
     deny from all
     </Files>

And htaccess in wp-admin directory

    Order Deny,Allow
    Deny from all
    Allow from xx.xxx.xx.x

Since then, I didn't receive any new suspicious login attempt on my Wordpress website Dashboard.
answers.title: Login attempts on Wordpress while wp-login and wp-admin restricted by htaccess
